dt: {bc}to restore by replacing a part or putting together what is torn or broken {bc}{sx|fix||}
{bc}to restore to a sound or healthy state {bc}{sx|renew||}

pt: {sc}mend{/sc} {sc}repair{/sc} {sc}patch{/sc} {sc}rebuild{/sc} mean to put into good order something that is injured, damaged, or defective. {sc}mend{/sc} implies making whole or sound something broken, torn, or injured.
{sc}repair{/sc} applies to the fixing of more extensive damage or dilapidation.
{sc}patch{/sc} implies an often temporary fixing of a hole or break with new material.
{sc}rebuild{/sc} suggests making like new without completely replacing.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}reparer{/it}, from Latin {it}reparare{/it}, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}parare{/it} to prepare {ma}{mat|pare|}{/ma}
shortdef: to restore by replacing a part or putting together what is torn or broken : fix
to restore to a sound or healthy state : renew
to make good : compensate for : remedy
